Dear David R Permaloff:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 08/12/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Corrective action plan must be submitted in CWLM.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Erica Marshall, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4407-1 Facility and premises maintenance
(1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a
clean, comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall
be located on land that is properly drained.
During the on-site visit on 7/29/25 the facility indicated they had not requested an
Environmental Health Inspection (EHI) from their local health department. When
an inspection was received on 8/4/25 the inspection was completed on the

incorrect form and with the incorrect rules. As of the date of this report a correct
EHI has not been received.
The health inspector did find the following:
• The Bathroom/Shower had holes in the walls/tile
• There were no test strips for the cleaning solution.
• The facility needs to use a cleaning solution that has a chemical
concertation verifiable with test strips. i.e. bleach or ammonia.
CCI Rule 400.4409-2 Ventilation
(2) During fly season, between May 1 and October 31,
each door, window, and other opening to the outside
which is used for ventilation purposes shall be
supplied with standard screens of not less than 16
mesh. Each screen door shall have a self- closing
device in working condition and shall swing outward.
The Living Room window was missing a screen.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The application, environmental and fire inspections were not complete upon
visit to the agency. The facility was able to get the fire and environmental
inspection completed on 8/4/2025 but the environmental was completed
incorrectly. This late request for the inspections does not leave enough time to
work out any violations or issues prior to the expiration of the license. EHI’s for
CCI’s need to be completed utilizing the form specifically for CCI’s and the
facility should be ensuring they are requesting this of their health inspector.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency did not require consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance

The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had one CAP as a result of SIR #2024SIC0001687 dated 8/15/24 with
a CAP approval date of 03/21/2025. The facility was found in violation of Rule
109(1)(c) Program statement due to staff using tobacco products and not doing
an incident report; Rule 128(3) Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training
due to staff lacking the required training hours and orientation; Rule 126 (1)
Sufficiency of staff due to inadequate staffing and appropriate supervision.
Ongoing monitoring of CAP compliance continues. The employee involved in this
incident was terminated. The facility was able to confirm termination of staff via
review of HR file and letter of termination during agency visit on 4/16/2025. The
facility has been able to provide policy highlights during staff meeting for the
month of November via meeting agenda and staff sign in log during agency visit
on 1/17/25. The facility was able to provide a spreadsheet template for
documentation of IR reports during agency visit on 1/17/25.
The facility had one CAP as a result of their 2024 Interim Audit and the CAP was
approved on 03/28/2025. The following violations were found:
• Rule 155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care institutions;
initial treatment plans due to missing social service worker or supervisor
signatures.
• Rule 113 (1) (i) Employee records due to employee files not have timely
central registry clearances.
• Rule 128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing training due to staff not
having the required orientation or annual training hours.
• Rule 152(1) (i) Initial documentation due to the facility failing to
document that they provided the youth with the grievance policy.
• Rule 156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care institutions;
updated treatment plans due to plans not being completed timely and
not having a supervisor signature.
• Rule 166 (1) (e) Discharge plan due to the plans missing documentation
that the recommendations were reviewed with the required individuals.
The facility has worked to bring the CAPs into compliance and as evidenced by
the lack of repeat violations have had success at implementing their corrective
actions.

Chief Administrator Assessment
This year has been a transitional period for the Sanctuary program, including
changes in key leadership roles. The Director of Homeless Youth Programs
position experienced turnover, and both the Counseling Manager and Case
Manager left the organization within a one-month span. Although offers were
extended and accepted by qualified candidates for these roles, both offers
ultimately fell through due to circumstances unrelated to Lighthouse Sanctuary.
The Chief Administrator reported ongoing difficulty in maintaining staff in critical
positions such as the Director, Manager of Counseling, Case Manager, and
Residential Specialists. Despite these staffing challenges, current Sanctuary staff
have significantly increased their familiarity with CCI licensing rules. As a result,
compliance has improved across several areas, including those cited in the 2024
Corrective Action Plan (CAP), with all concerns now fully addressed and
corrected.
In September 2024, a new Quality Performance and Compliance Manager
position was created. David Permaloff was hired at the end of that month and has
since taken on the role of Chief Administrator for CCI licensure. Following the
resignation of the RHY Program Director at the end of September 2024, L’Vette
Ramsey was hired in March 2025 as the new Director.
To further enhance compliance oversight, a comprehensive internal compliance
checklist was recently developed and will be implemented by RHY leadership.
Internal reviews will now take place twice a year to monitor licensing compliance,
in addition to the annual CA assessment.
Progress and corrections have been made on all violations noted in the previous
CAP. All staff submitted their annual CPS clearance request forms in June 2025,
and clearance results were received in July 2025. Initial treatment plans for both
Sanctuary and ASF residents are being completed by counseling staff and are
reviewed, approved, and countersigned by supervisory staff, which may include
the Counseling Manager, RHY Director, or Chief Administrator.
A structured training plan has been created through the Relias training platform to
ensure all staff meet the minimum requirement of 25 hours annually. New staff
are receiving an additional 25–30 hours of training, including orientation and
selected external trainings, such as courses offered through the RHYTECH
training platform. Staff files are being reviewed to ensure compliance with CCI
new hire requirements, including verification of three references, education, TB
testing, fingerprinting (FBI clearance), CPS clearance, and CPR certification.
Incident Reports are being completed and reviewed promptly. When required,
reports are submitted to the Licensing Consultant. All incidents involving police
contact or staff involvement are being reported within the designated timeframes.

CAP-related activities have positively impacted programming. Staff have shown
increased engagement in meeting training requirements. Given the high rate of
staff turnover, all new employees receive written documentation outlining training
expectations and immediate access to the Relias platform.
The RHY Program Manager developed a comprehensive orientation plan that
has been completed by all current staff and is now implemented on the first day
of employment for new staff. This ensures all team members meet required
training standards from the onset of employment.
Unplanned discharges have been rare, with only two youth experiencing
unplanned discharges during the reporting period.
• The first case involved a youth who fled from school and abandoned their
transportation following a school suspension. The youth later contacted
Sanctuary staff, expressing stress and a desire to take a break from the
program. The youth returned to retrieve personal belongings. Staff
attempted to deescalate the situation, but the youth left on foot. Royal Oak
Police were contacted to initiate runaway protocol. The youth's mother
gave police permission to transport the youth to the hospital, where she
met them. The mother later called The Sanctuary to express her gratitude
for the staff’s dedication and efforts to ensure her child’s safety.
• The second case involved a youth who requested to leave the program
after being informed that eating in their bedroom was not permitted. The
youth contacted police, expressing frustration over chores and a desire to
go to the hospital. The youth's mother was contacted and chose to take
the youth to the hospital herself. The youth self-discharged and did not
return to the program.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed expressed overall satisfaction with the program, highlighting its
focus on providing shelter, therapeutic services, life skills, and wellness activities
to youth. They reported that children are respected, receive adequate therapeutic
support, and generally get along well with each other. Staff emphasized the
importance of clear communication with youth and noted feeling supported and
confident in their roles, including during crisis intervention. Several staff members
expressed a need for more full-time staff to enhance continuity of care and
relationship-building. A common concern raised was the mixing of youth from the
A Step Forward (ASF)and Basic Sanctuary Center ( BSC) programs, as each
program has different structures and rules—ASF focuses on independent living
while BSC is more structured. This overlap can lead to confusion and conflict
among the youth, particularly around differing expectations such as curfew times
and telephone usage. For example, ASF youth may have later curfews and more
flexible phone access, while BSC youth follow stricter time constraints and limited
phone privileges, which can cause tension or feelings of unfairness. Staff
suggested separating the two populations to better support their distinct needs and
maintain consistency in expectations.

Youth interviewed from the A Step Forward program expressed overall satisfaction
with their experience and indicated that the program is meeting their needs. They
reported feeling safe, well-supported by staff, and having access to adequate food.
Several youth highlighted enjoying the meals, with one noting a particular interest
in cooking. All youth confirmed participation in both group and individual therapy
and expressed that they feel comfortable engaging in the services offered. One
youth mentioned an interest in transitioning into the Graduated Apartment Program
(GAP) program and stated that they would not change anything about their current
experience. No concerns were raised by the youth during the interviews.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the facility occurred during the inspection on 07/31/25. The facility was
clean and in good condition. There were no safety concerns noted during the
inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
